With more then superficiall care, t'injoyne
A penance for your folly; the light smoake
Findes not a surer buriall in the a yre
(To whose embraces with ambitious haste.
On azure wings it soar'd) then has your guilt,
In this forgiving bosome, this pure kisse seales the agreement.

sp.speaker: Sir Mar.
sp.l: She offred first too, and me thought she kis'd
As she would eate my lips, the ravenous touch
Of her hot flesh has seard me up like grasse
In summer time, and her fowle breath like blasts
Of Southerne windes, has quickned my dead fire
Of jealousie, nay rais'd it to a greater
Heat then my former.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: What ayle you sir on the suddaine?

sp.speaker: Sir Mar.
sp.l: Viper, toad, out of my presence, ere my just wak'd
Rage, get to its height, whence like a Falcon towring
At full pitch ore the trembling fowle, it will sease on thee.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Madam tis best to leave him, I feare he's absolutly franticke; Vrinall looke to him, least he act some violence on himselfe, please your Ladiship withdraw.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Soft patience guard my heart: wheres no offence, one safely may rely on innocence.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: Why sir Martine, how doe you sir? not speak? now by my life, hee lookes like a staggerell newly come to his Hornes, flings his head just in that manner they do not touch the seeling, yet Sir Martine: in time they may be three and foure at top, and serve to hang hats and cloakes on in the best knights hall in towne.

sp.speaker: Sir Mar.
sp.p: O Vrinall.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: O Vrinall, what a pittifull noate was there, that very sound has almost crack'd me to pieces: Sir Martine, good Sir Martine what ayles you? or rather what ayles your wife, that you hum and haw so after kissing her, her breath is savory, I dare bee sworne shee has neither eaten Onions nor drunke Aqua-vitae.

sp.speaker: Sir Mar.
sp.l: O no, she is like a too ripe, so extreamely sweet,
Shee poisons like the hony which small Bees
Sucke from the Aconite, the Panther so
Breaths odors pretious as the Sarmaticke gums
Of Easterne groves, but the delicious sent not taken in at
Distance choakes the sense with the too muskie savor.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: You should have kis'd her as the Court fashion is, upon the cheeke, but pray sir, why are you so jealous: yet cannot prove your Lady has a trick with her toe, or turnes oftner then an honest woman (if shee do) had not you better like an old Stag, cast the cognisance of your order into the hedge, then like a wanton Pricket, runne full Butte at every one you meet, as who should say; take notice of my horns. I am ashamed of it so I am.

sp.speaker: S. Mar.
sp.p: Do'st not believe I am? a hideous cuckold.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: And must you needs cry Cuckow therefore. There are knights in towne who know their Ladies to be Hens oth' game, and liue by tredding, yet like mettle Cockes they never hang the Gills for't, they are sure faire Gamesters use to pay the boxe well: especially at In, and In, (the Innes of Court Butlers would have had but a bad Christmas of it else) and what care they, so they can purchase plush, though their wives pay ith' hole for it.

sp.speaker: Sir Mar.
sp.p: Can there be such monsters?

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: Monsters, they are men Sir Martine, such as you are; only they are velvet browd a little: but heare me Sir, if a man would venture faire offer to give a certaine knowledge of your wifes honesty.

sp.speaker: Sir Mar.
sp.p: Doe that, and be my genius Vrinall.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: You would have an evill Angell of me, Ile tell you sir, my master intends privately this night to wed his daughter to the Dutch younker Sconce, the house will be atquiet, and your Lady left alone in her chamber, her sister Mistris Knoworth, being to goe to Church with them.

sp.speaker: Sir Mar.
sp.p: What of this?

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: Soft and faire Sir Martine, I will ith' evening steale you into the Ladies chamber when she's in bed, come to her, and in the darke, (that's the only time to deale with a woman) (and as another man) trie what you can doe with her: if she consent (the worst) you doe but cuckold your selfe, if hold out, being a woman alone, in bed, and in the dark having a man standing by her, you may then conclude her an honest wife, and your jealousie foolish, as your vexation needlesse, you thinke I have no wit now I warrant.

sp.speaker: Sir Mar.
sp.p: According as my soule could wish.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p:
Why law you then, who's the foole now? Sir Martine
come in the evening, I will not faile you.

sp.speaker: Sir Mar.
sp.l: Nor I hopes of triall, fare you well,
A jealous man has in his heart his hell.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: well knight, if I doe not fit your jealous head, let me bee sung in ballads for an erranter coxcombe then your selfe.

div.stage: Enter Mistris Artlesse, Mistris Mixum, and Dalinea.

sp.speaker: Mist. Art.
sp.p: Well said minx, you will not have him: but you had best consider and doe as I and your father would have you: or you shall trudge for it, you shall be his wife.

sp.speaker: Mist. Mix.
sp.p: Nay in sadnesse Mistris Dal. you are too blame, the gentleman is an honest gentleman, I and a kinde man I warrant him to a woman; your mother and I have made triall of him, and finde him of a very good disposition, come chicke you shall have him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Art.
sp.p: Nay let her chuse and bee hangd, proud baggage who will refuse a gentleman of my owne chusing, but Ile send him to you and see if thou darst deny him, for thy life, come Mistris Mixum.

div.stage: Exeunt Mistris Artlesse and Mistris Mixum.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: Was ever innocent virgin thus betrayd
By cruelty of parents, who for wealth
Have sold my youth to slavery, the cold
Ashes of injurd maids surround my heart,
Or some divine dew, stead of blood replenish
My swelling veins, circle my thought with Ice,
Thou power of chastity, that like the fresh
Primrose uncropt, by any hand, I may
Returne my selfe as pure and white
To earth, as when I came from't.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: How doe you Mistris Dal. alasse poore gentlewoman, would they have thee coverd with a Frisland horse, a Dutch Stallion: now shame upon their soules that wish it, he's neighing here already.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p:
Vrinall, my cosen Fortresse and the rest oth' Knights will be here presently; pray you prepare the musicke and the wine,
I would not faile in the most diminute ceremony.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: Of a most absolute coxcombe, I shall provide them sir.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Now begins my horror, the fatall Bell should it proclaime my death, were spheare-like musicke to his night-crowes voyce; yet I must heare it and retaine my sense, continue subject to a daily noyse from the ill boding monster.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Lady or Madamosell, Vfroe or Seniora, what you please, or in what language to be entituled the Mistris of my thoughts, the complemental garbe is customary, and though I have learn'd by conversation with the Twibill Knights to kisse my hand, believe me I had rather bestow my lips on yours; our naturall Dutch contracting is the best, without deceit or shadow, there we only goe to th' taverne and be ungue browd, then drunke together. Ther's all our ceremony, and tis lawfull marriage too.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Would you would sir, better consider with your selfe and match where your own customes are observ'd, my feare my quality will never suite the liking of your Dutch manners.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Manners Lady, you mistake I've none at all; ere we will disagree about manners, Ile be as clownish as an Upland Bore, foutra, tell a Dutch man of manners?

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Yet sir have so much charity.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: We detest that worse then the former, tis Papisticall, and was with that religion banish'd our reform'd Common-wealth: but to our businesse, pretty soule, I shall give thee touch mon and get a burger of thee.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: Gentle sir, there ought to be in manhood a divine
Pitty, believe me as I tender truth,
I cannot set the smallest of my thoughts
On your ill welcome love, therefore I beseech you
Not to proceed in my unfortunate match
Which will be fatall to us both, for goodnesse
Have so much mercy on me.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p:
An excellent touch that, as if there could be mercy in a Dutch-man, and to a woman? if there had beene any, the Nuns at Tilmont had not beene us'd so horribly last summer: why should you say you cannot love me tis a false touch I me certaine of it, I shall know anone, till when receive your lips in pledge
that no such words shall issue forth of them, adiew Lady, anone we must to the old touch of Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Dal
sp.l: The hand of death
Shall give me first a bride to some darke grave,
Where I will mixe with wormes before the Priest
Knit so unjust an union, the kinde grasse
Will sure be greene still on my Sepulchre, and spotlesse
Virgins annually dance a fairy ring about it.

div.stage: Enter Vrinall and Popingay in disguised clothes.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: Now if you doe not catch a Roach in her troubled waters, I shall conclude you a gudgion: speake to her; a woman has ever a hole open to receive a mans tale, believe it you shall have my assistance, and if I doe not second you confidently, may my tongue be cramped, my wit breech'd; and the machina of my invention ruind perpetually.

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.p: Fairest creature.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: Had you said wretched'st, Mistris you had given me
My proper attribute.

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.l: Can there be on earth,
A savagenesse so great as will conspire
To afflict so rich a goodnesse? yet by your eyes
Adorn'd by those cleare pearles which doe transforme
Even sorrow to a lovelinesse beyond
Indifferent beauty, I conceive some fiend
Rested in humane shape (for man would never
Have dar'd so vile a sacrilege) in hope
By your pure teares, t'extinguish his owne flames
Caus'd this distemper in you.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.l: Pish you are long to speed, be
Short and quick, that pleases Ladies.

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.l: I had a younger brother, though not fully blest
In your sweet knowledge, yet once his tounge
Was his hearts bold embassador, and deliver'd
A true narration of his zealous love,
Which is in him so permanent, that when
his eares receive a notice that your faith
Is plighted to another, twill be juice
Of balefull hemlocke to his braine, convert it
Either to suddaine madnesse or a sleep, cold and erelasting.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: I remember once a nephew of Sir Martines did sollicit
That which he term'd my love, but I conceiv'd
His meaning rather was to cause discourse,
Then that his strict intention had resolved
His promises performance.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.l: Did I not tell you she would come about?

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.l: Trust me Lady, the solitary Nightingale who sings
To her lost honour a harmonious ditty,
Loves not the thorne so dearely, to whose pricks
She sets her featherd bosome, as I me sure
My brother tenders you, the gawdy light
May sooner be obscur'd by wandring smoake:
Nay the eternall essence of the soule
Become corporeall and revisite earth,
After its flight to paradise, ere he
Descend to variation of his love, could you affect him.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: Had your brother been
Of the same disposition and soft sweetnesse
That I perceive in you (though this be our
First enterview) there could not have beene molded
(Had I beene borne to entertaine loves heat)
A man that would so fitly sympathize
With my condition, nor whom I should fancy
With more intire perfection.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.l: Strike home, and sure the iron's hot already,

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.l: Behold him Lady,
Whose every motion does as from the spheare,
Receive a lively influence from your lookes;
The modest silence of the temperate Even,
When zephire softly murmures to the flowers
A wholesome farewell undisturb'd by stormes,
May sooner rest in one continued night,
Then can my soule in quiet without just
Assurance of your love, which if you grant,
Times native Belman, the shield Organd Cocke
Shall cease to carroll Muttens to the morne,
The earely Larke that whispers to the Sun
A constant Augury of a beauteous day,
Shall lose his light plumes in the checkerd Clouds,
Ere I my resolute chastity, nor can you
Invent evasions to declare my suite,
Since on its grant relyes the only hopes
Of your redemption from the barbarous armes,
Of him you were espous'd to.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: This surprize,
And your strong vowes would batter a resolve,
Downe in a brest that could be flexible
To easy love, but since I cannot frame
My conscience to a warrantable zeale
Toward any man, Ile rather fixe my hate
(For that must of necessity accrue
To him that weds me) on a person worthy
Contempt, then on your selfe, whose worth do's challenge
A noble and reciprocall regard
For your affection, blessings on ye sir, thinke not amisse of me.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: Now the curse of a tedious virginity light on ye, you will not be tupped by a Dutch Ram, a Hausen Kender, a West-fally Bore-pig, now the iniquity of a swagbellied Hollands Burgers get thee with childe of a dropsie, if thou marriest him, why how now Master Popingay, stroken with a Plannet? tis a female Star, as changeable as the Moone, goe to your chamber, I heare company approaching, this Dutch Butter-Firkin shall bee melted to grease ere he shall have her, trust to it.

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.l: Passion on passion fall when hopes are spent,
The best of comforts is a forc'd content.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.l: So here comes my blades, now plot but hit,
And Vrinall shall be stil'd the Lord of wit.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p:
Cosen Fortresse welcome, welcome Captaine Pirke, valiant brothers, nay gentlemen, then your accoutrements be of
the vulgar cut, be not daunted, tis hereditary to Low Country souldiers to weare off reckonings, the time shall come the little worme shall weave, and silken tribute pay to men of service, give me your hands gentlemen, I shall be one of you anone, but Cosen Fortresse, what bashfull youth is that that dares not thrust his nose out of his coate, for feare the winde should blow it to his face, ha?

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.p: Tis flat enough already, this my Jo, nay show thy Phisnomy, h'is our quondam trusty attendant, but now Knight of the Twibill, Pithagoras Pig.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Is this the famous off-spring of great hog? we should be kindred certainely, my Ancestors were Bores, give me thy forefoot sirrha, and tell me coz, why dost not wander into a new skin? this begins to crackle vilely.

sp.speaker: Pirk.
sp.p: O tis for want of basting sir.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.p: No my Jo, hee casts his skin but once a yeare, like the poore snake: well, he has done our Order speciall service; but coz, where are the preparations the vancarriors coz, to the solemnity of your instalment? renounce me, if you vilifie the institution by disregard of properties, this hand shall never crosse the Twibill ore thy head, nor give thee thy avant chevalier, while thou art mortall my Jo, I say I shall not.

sp.speaker: Pirk.
sp.p: No matter sir Sconce, by the head of valor, my selfe shall dub thee.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.p: Who you King Twadle? Mushrome you dub him?

sp.speaker: Pirk.
sp.p: Yes, I Gog, Magog, I dub him Garantua.

sp.speaker: Scon
sp.p: Nay good cosen Fortresse, Captaine Pirke, this Vrinall I could e'ne fill him to the brim with curses, but here's my agent; come where are the musitioners Vrinall?

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: They will bee loud enough by and by, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.p: This is legitimate blood of the Spanish grape my Jo.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Lusty sacke credit me coz, twill give the touch, Vrinall make fast the doore, and leave us, and give us notice if any body approach.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: What haste this gull makes to cheat himselfe in private, must the musicke enter?

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: No by no meanes, weel call to them through the doore, varlet avoide.
Now coz, to beginne our ceremony; first, drinke to me.

sp.speaker: Scon:
sp.p: I like it well when it begins with drinks, tis a signe twill end merrily; this cup is abominable to little, one can scarce wet his whistle out of it, it shall be this goblet, a vostre grace, coz Fortresse.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.p: Sir Pithagoras we doe create you skinker, it shall goe round my blades, you shall dible in liquor of account; here brother Make-shift.

sp.speaker: Make,
sp.p: Gramercies Captaine.

sp.speaker: Pirk.
sp.p: Choake you sir, learne manners, offer to drinke before betters, tis an affront to seniority, destroy me if I can suffer this, no forsake me Captaine I cannot.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: There was a touch for you brother Makeshift, but good little Pirke be patient.

sp.speaker: Mak.
sp.p: This Preface is very Cannonical my Io, nay, I shal learn the phrases instantly.

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: Have you all had it brothers?

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: All but my selfe Sir Holofernes.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Who my coz Pig, off sup off thy wash my Jo, at worst thou canst but be swine-drunke; but coz, shall we dispatch? I long to be instald.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.p: I now we'l to't, come hither Captaine, sing the hymne preparatory to Knight-hood, but wet your pipes first, Ganimed, they'l squeake the better.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: An admirable touch this, what's next troe?

sp.speaker: Fort
sp.p: Now coz Sconce, our Order does constraine us to a frisk, a dance about you, as the Fairies tred about their great King Oberon.

sp.speaker: Pirk.
sp.p: But can this musicke play the Twibill dance, none else will satisfie.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Musicke you must play the Twibill dance he sayes, dance so while.

sp.speaker: Dance.
sp.p: They dance, the wine shall tread a sink apace into my belly, you have lost one of your best heels cosen.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.p: No me Jo, twas off before the ceremony is halfe accomplish'd, you are our wardrope keeper, brother Knockedowne have you brought the vestments of our Order?

sp.speaker: Knocke.
sp.p: Fuse Captaine not I.

sp.speaker: Pirk.
sp.p: Rot me sir, you would be made to fetch them.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: How, not our robes of honor the ensignes of our chevalry?

sp.speaker: Knock.
sp.p: Sinke me, sir you know they are in tribulation.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Hell take the Broker: we must perforce imploy one of our owne suits.

sp.speaker: Knock
sp.p: Take my Buffe Jerkin Captaine.

sp.speaker: Make.
sp.p: Death keepe it on, you'll shew your dirty shirt.

sp.speaker: Pirke.
sp.p: Found you sir, you lye: I fathome in your guts, hee has none on.

sp.speaker: Make.
sp.p: How, sonne of foule Adultery, the lye?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: What doe you blunder, whifflers Pigge, are you grunting too: shall I whet my Twibill on your bones mips of debility?

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Nay, Cosen, Gentlemen rather than you shall fall out, Ile be content to bee dub'd in my own cloathes: nay pray you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Tis against order, and we must observe ceremony.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: O by all meanes Coz.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: First then receive this cap of maintenance.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Cap of Maintenance doe you call it? I will maintaine when this old Cap was new, 'twas a Dutch felt, but now tis nine degrees below a straw Hat; I doe not like this touch: but Coz I shall have my Bever agen I hope?

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.p: How? suspitious my Io: Brother Knockdowne disroab his necke of this old linnen, savours of a winding-sheet: this is Decimo Sexto, feares no rumpling: Now Cosen Sconce, you must discusse your doublet.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: That will be damn'd instantly; pray heaven my skinne scape.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Here sir, receive this Military Cassocke, 't has seene service.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: 'Thas been shot through both the Elbowes; this Military Cassocke has I feare, some Military hangbyes: this Twibill Knight-hood is but a lousie Order, would I had he're medled with it.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.p: Now you appeare something above an Embrio: Make-shift helpe to untrusse his breeches.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: I shall be whipt instantly: But Cozen Fortresse, is there no redemption for my Breeches?

sp.speaker: Pirke.
sp.p: Sume me Captaine, tis not requisite he should put off his Breeches.

sp.speaker: Scon
sp.p: Thankes good Captaine Pirke, twas a friendly touch that

sp.speaker: Pir.
sp.p: May not his transitory money serve to excuse his breeches?

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.p: To him it may.

sp.speaker: Pir.
sp.p: A Twibill Knight ought to regard no money, but the glistring steele.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Well, since it must be so, there take my money.

sp.speaker: Knock.
sp.p: Paw sir, you lose the priviledge of the Order, if you respect your money.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Now doe I looke like as if I were new come from the Lottery: or what say you Sir Holofernes, to the Picture of the Prodigal in the painted Cloath? Sure I have now perform'd all the Ceremonies; if not, I me sure I have nothing else left to performe withall.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.p: So, now kneele downe, while thus I thee create: Ieremias Sconce, Knight of the order of Twibill. Now avaunt Chevaleire.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Health to our worthy Brother, Ieremias Sconce, Knight of the Twibill.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.p: But brothers, there is Sacke yet to be drunke, in Celebration of this Knight-hood,

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: I like this drinking heartily; there's some goodnesse in't: will you beginne, my Captaine Generall; Ile call you so now.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.p: Pythagoras, fill his Bowle up. Capt.. Pirk this Cornucopia To my Leiftenant Generalls health: Ile call you so now.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: A place of Marke and Charge that.

sp.speaker: Pirke.
sp.p: Man of valour, respect this Cup to the health of our Leift. Generall Generall.

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: A vous brother Knockdowne.

sp.speaker: Knock.
sp.p: Here Sir Barrabas.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Altogether gentlemen, a health Musitians, sound .Gentlemen all tres humblement serviture vostre: I ha done you right.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.p: Expect me Io; heart of my father, you must for consummation of your installment, drinke a cup a piece to each of us.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Twas my intention Generall: to you all in generall, helpe Pith. let it be be two Captaine, tis pitty to put so many worthy men in a pint pot.

sp.speaker: Perk.
sp.p: Soule of my valour, y'are ship'd sir, you must drinke five together.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Y'are wanton Captaine, a wag upon my Knight-hood, you meane to measure the profundity of my belly, twill bee a hard taske to doe it to a Dutch-man looke you Captaine.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.p: Thou shalt be my Bacchus Io, he drinkes as if hee had eaten Pickle Herring.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: This Cup was as deepe as Fleet-street Conduit. Sound me my Io, I ha' made a new River in my Belly, and my Guts are the Pipes: Tother cup good wreckling, vertue shall be vertue still, so long as I can stand Captaine.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.p: That will not be long I hope.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: This Coller spoyles my drinking, or else this Sack has horse-flesh in't, it rides upon my stomacke. O Vrinall, Ime a Knight of the Twibill honest Vrinall.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: Take heede you'll crush me sir to pieces. Gentlemen yonder are the Constables at the doore to apprehend Captaine Fortresse.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Some more sacke sirrah, I shall be married anon.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: That's I, tis for the linnen brothers: Hell my Io, how shall I scape them?

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: More Sacke sirrah, the tother touch sweet Pig, the tother touch.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: There is no way but one sir, they have beset the house; my Master is perswading them. Follow mee, Ile by a backe way set you safely out with your company.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Noble Vrinall: come Blades here's purchase for us.

sp.speaker: Scor.
sp.p: This is but foure Cups captaine Cosen Pigge. Skinke my parting Cup, and then I me gone: ha! where be you Gentlemen, I am not blinde, or play you at Boe-peep? they are gone, this is a pretty touch, my touch my Io, with my money and Cloathes, a pretier touch still, let me see, they have left some Sacke behind them, there's my comfort yet.
sp.stage: Ent. Poping. and Lovring in womans cloaths.
sp.l: Who's this? my wife that must bee.
Come hither wife, thou seest the worst of me
sp.p: I am but drunke: Kisse me Borankee: never feare, I will not spoyle thy gorget. Hark in thy eare my Io, shall I have a gentle touch? twill doe no harme, wee are to be marryed anon thou know'st; I shall get wise children on thee.

sp.speaker: Lov
sp.p: What wouldst thou ravish me libidinous Swine? Strive, and thou dyest.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Twas an unkinde touch that, my Io, you might have falne under me, 't had beene the fitter place for a woman, (pray helpe me up agen.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Yes, to thy death, if thou deny t' performe what I enjoyne thee.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: How, kill a knight of the Twibill, and in the Ensignes of his owne Order, ere it shall be said to the disgrace of Knight-hood, that any of the fraternity was kild by a woman, Ile doe any thing: Lead on, Ile follow you.

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.l: Thus they must strive,
Who in loves subtle Merchandise will thrive.

div.head: Actus Quintus, Scena prima.
div.stage: Enter Doctor, Vrinall, Mris. Artlesse, and Mris. Mixum.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: THis stealth was unexpected, tis almost
Beyond beliefe, my daughter should thus change
Her perverse humour, and embrace his love
Which when I motion'd to her, the darke shade
Seem'd not a greater enemy to blest light
Than she appeard to it: and that she should
Cosen my hopes, and without me her mother,
Or any friend resigne her will to his,
And strike the match up, puzzles my best faith,
Though I rejoyce at it.

sp.speaker: Vrin
sp.p:
You have reasons sir to doe so, your daughter had more wit then you expected, tis the quality of maids, to deny what they desire: had you but seene how nimbly shee trod over the threshold; you would have sworne she had beene mad of the match: I stood and heard him aske her: shall wee goe to the
Church answerd she, ist not too late quoth he agen, never too late to doe well replied she agen: (though it were at midnight) and then the Dutch younker tooke her up into a (what doe you call it) a sedan (and heaven speed) away they went, marry to what Church, he's gone I know not, only I heard him sweare he would not come at Pencridge.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Art.
sp.p: And why not; tis an ancient Church, and all old things must not be cast away, there has beene many an honest couple given to the lawfull bed there, so there has.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: No matter for that, he protested he would be marryd in a Taverne ere that pencridge, there's no drinke nere it; but at the Pinder of Wakefield, and that's abominable, and he has vowd to season their bargaine with a cup of Sacke ere they returne.

sp.speaker: Mist. Art.
sp.p: Hee will not bee drunke on's wedding night I hope; my daughter would have a sweet bed-fellow of him, if he should.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: There is another loving couple gone with them too for company, who will be man and wife if the Priest say Amen to it.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: who are they of our knowledge?

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: O yes sir, tis Master Lovering, the attendant to Master Knoworth, and Sir Martines Niece that came but yesterday.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Is't possible? twas some slie policy of her Uncles to bring her hither, Master Lovering knew her before it seemes.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: Too well I feare sir, they would not have marryd in such post haste else.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mix.
sp.p: Well Master Doctor, I hope my gloves shall bee better then the ordinary, I had no small hand in this match, you know.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Tis nine a clocke at least: twill not belong ere they returne, wife pray goe in and see all things in readinesse for their lodgings.

sp.speaker: Mist. Art.
sp.p: They will have more stomacks to their beds then to their suppers.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: To morrow we'l celebrate their nuptiall feast: Vrinall be you carefull of the doores; let none come in but our owne company.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: Ile locke them up, and keepe the keyes my selfe sir, Mrs. Mixum your husband is with them, and in his absence I would desire a word with you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mix.
sp.p: I love to talke with any man in my husbands absence; sweet Vrinall I will fulfill your pleasure, will you goe Mistris?
sp.stage: Ex. Vrin. Mrs. Art. & Mrs. Mix.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: So now have at her.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Have I not plotted finely? has my braine
not won the lawrell garland the famd breath
That wafts the honor of deserving wits
Among the humorous multitude (as lowd
As it speakes conquering triumphs) shall proclaime
My politicke merit, who have raised my selfe
From worse then no name in the judging world,
To an indifferent wealth, which though ive got
By wayes sinister, such as erre from truth:
Nay might incurre a punishment no eyes
Has ere discern'd them, but with wonder how
I should atchieve such fortune, now compleat
In this alliance.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Sister, let's to our chambers and to bed,
That time approaches.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Your good Ladiship (I hope) will honour me so much
As for an houre to dispense with rest,
And see my bride in bed.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Your bride good Master Doctor, who should that be?
I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: My daughter Ladies, that to me
And all the house seem'd so averse from marriage,
Is this night stolne forth with younker Sconce,
And is by this time wedded to him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Beyond wonder, well sir,
We'l have her bride garters, it shall goe
Hard else, sister could you have thought it?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: You may both credit it, instantly they will returne, and
Then Ile wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I pitty the poore girle,
That she should be so suddaine in her choyce,
Enthrall her soule ith' manacles of fate,
(For such are nuptiall bonds) experience sister
Inforces me to lament her Know

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.l: How equally we two
Divide true, sorrow sympathize in griefe,
As in our blood and nature: sister you
When your affectionate fancy fix'd your heart
Upon your husbands love, had no suspition
Of his unmanly jealousie, and I
When I confin'd my love to Free Freewit's breast,
Judg'd him as void of falshood, as the spring
When it has rested in green robes the Earth is
Of bare nakednesse, but we are both
Deceiv'd by our credulity.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: For you, discretion may release you from the care
Of his affection, you are free (as light)
(Which in the darkest night retaines some splendor)
From the obedient slavery, due to marriage;
But I no burne-markd captive is engag'd
With more officious zeale to serve his Lord,
Then I my husband, I must either perish
Like the chaste ice, when from a Christ all Rocke,
It feeles a sad conversion into fowle
Corrupted waters, by his jealous flames;
Or breake those ties whose dissolution
Would betray my innocent vertue to a ruine,
Sure and eternall.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.l: But yet counsell me,
I love this man so that if honour would
Dispense with his offence, I should forgive him,
And take him to my bosome

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Alasse you cannot,
What noble soule (though halfe starv'd) would be fed with
Base reversions, conscience too forbids.
The supplantation of another, sister strive to forget him

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: Mrs. there is a gentleman without, this knockt for entrance as if he had beene a Constable, his businesse is with you, and his name Freewit; I told him you were in bed and he swore he would come to you through the doore, shall I admit him?

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.p: This is his last night, his businesse carryes weight, pray let him in. Be now propitious Love: is any with him?

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: There is enough of him, unlesse he made lesse noise. Ile send him to you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Sister, now give him his latest answer, and resolve
Upon some choise more happy: here he comes.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.l: How, as a Bridegroome?
Deckt with the Ensignes of young Nuptialls,
A wreath of Flowers, and Bayes, and yet me thinkes
His hand displayes a Willow: what should this Embleme?
Master Freewit we scarce expected you thus late.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: You'll please to afford my manners an indulgent pardon,
For pressing to your presence thus: but tis
Perhaps our extremest enterview, and so
May challenge the prerogative of excuse,
For the audacious errour.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.p: Would I could, with as much safety to my honour, grant Remission to your other fault.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: My thanks, are humble debtors to you for it, Mistris,
The nimble minutes have with crafty theft,
Stolne time away, reduc'd your limited houre
To an unwelcome period: I have sought
With the same diligence good men seeke heaven,
What you injoyn'd me, but the raine that falls
In Summer time upon the parched dust,
May easier be restor'd to the moyst Clouds,
Then she to my discovery. Wherefore since
Her losse is certaine, and the losse of you
Depends on her, to satisfie your soule
That I have man about me, I am come
With the same confidence your scorne has taught me,
To tell you, I as lightly prize your love,
As you have valued mine, nor can you blame me, since 'twas your owne desire.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.l: Credit me I'me very glad on't: but pray tell me sir,
Why you come thus adorned with Nuptiall wreathes
Into my presence? is't to invite me to your wedding, or expression
Of your contempt, I have not merited so harsh an usage.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Neither: This branch of forsaken Willow I resigne
To your owne wearing, that when after times
Shall know our mutuall parting; 't may report,
That we were both forsaken, though we sever
With the unwillingnesse that flourishing trees,
Divest themselves of greenenesse, yet no blemish
Of harsh unkindnesse shall defile our thoughts:
We'll part faire, though for ever.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: This gentleman seems so noble, I repent that I advis'd her from him.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: This Laurell wreath, that circles
My uncaptiv'd brow, I doe justly challenge,
Since I have conquerd the greatest enemy,
Mankind can combate (passion) yet the dew
(That on the red lips of the blushing Rose
Bestowes a weeping kisse) leaves not so sadly
The amorous flower, that curles its purple leaves,
To hide it from the Suns enforcing Rayes,
As doe my thoughts your memory, which did once
Preserve it as inviolable, as heaven
Does the bright soules of innocents.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: You might
Have had so much humanity, as to have kept
Your purpose to your selfe: though your loose sinne
Constraines my honour to renounce your love,
I would not have my eares disturb'd with this
Relation of your contempt, for so
Trust me I take it Freewit.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Why, good Madam? can you condemne my too officious truth,
Of a conceite of falshood, when the spring
Of my Revolt, derives its head from yours.
You for a triviall, and scarce knowne offence,
Could without scruple banish me your heart,
When Angels should, for a desertlesse kisse
From an impure lip, have renounc'd their blisse,
Ere the most urgent reason of suspect,
Should upon me have practis'd a contempt
Of you: Had not your breath expos'd a mist
Of infidelity before the eyes
Of my cleare seeing soule, and left it blinde
As the blacke Mole, that like a Pioner digs
A winding Labyrinth through the earth to finde
A passage to the comfortable light,
He never has fruition of.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: But sir, suppose my sister did it for a proofe,
Of your affection, and now should reclaime
The harsh prescription she impos'd, you would not
Continue in this temper.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Madam ever. The Cedars juyce, whose bitter poyson gives
The most strong body unavoyded death,
Preserves the Carcasse by its dying force,
Voyd of corruption: so has dealt her love
With me; its reclamation strucke me dead,
And since my Exequies has kept my heart
From entertaining a corrupt regard
Of future slavery,

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: They are entred, sir, I heard Mr. Mix. say as I let them in, that they were marryed.

div.stage: Enter Mixum with a Torch, Popingaies in Sconce his cloaths, leading Dalinea: Lovering leading Sconce attired in Poping. womans cloaths.

sp.speaker: Mix.
sp.p: Nay, come an end gentlemen and your wives, Mr. Doctor wil not be angry though I have usurp'd his office, and beene the father to his daughter.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: You are not a cunning baggager you would none forsooth when I propos'd it to you; but when the fit came on you, you could then runne madding, and never let the Sexton ring the Bell to give us notice: had it beene any one but Mr. Sconce, you should have fought a portion; but since to him, we pardon it: take her sonne, heavens give thee joy of her.

sp.speaker: Vri.
sp.p: You would scarce say so, knew you as much as I doe.

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.p: We thanke you sir, and rest your dutifull children.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Ha! my Nephew Popingay!

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Mr. Popingaies. Sir Maritimes Nephew! I am abus'd, undone, my daughter's cousend Vrinall, a trick put on mee, Mr. Popingay to wed my daughter.

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.p: Twas with her owne consent Sir, and she my wife by your free gift.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Art.
sp.p: Your wife, your whore she is as soone, she is Master Sconces wife, and that you shall finde, so you shall, let me come to the baggage husband, Ile scratch her eyes out.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Ere he shall injoy her, Ile spend the best part of my wealth he shall not have a penny portion with her, depart my house I charge you Vrinall call in my neighbours, ere I'le be us'd thus.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: Harke you sir, you know I know you and your wayes.

sp.speaker: Vrin
sp.p: Doct. What talk'st thou varlet?

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: Goe to, be patient, then give this gentleman your daughter; nay be friends, and love him too, or all shall out.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Thou wilt not betray me villaine?

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.l: But I shall discover you and your practises, nay to the Justice,
This gentleman is the same Sir Martin brought hither as his Niece.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Plots upon plots against me.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: But the great one is still behinde: if you will be friends quickly with them, so; if not, your impostures all come out.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Is it even so? well since I am ore-reach'd.
Better sit downe in peace, than with disgrace:
Mr. Popingay consideration of your just desert,
Now his perswasion has suppress'd my heat,
Enjoyns me to forgive your loving theft;
Accept my daughter with as good a heart
As she is mine: come hither wife, say you so too?

sp.speaker: Mris. Art.
sp.p: Nay, since you say it, it must be so.

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.l: Humbly I thanke you: such another gift,
Should Nature offer all her pretious store,
Could not be given Mortality: but truely sir,
I had much adoe to winne her.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: You have me now;
But I professe untill we came to be
Conjoyn'd ith' Church, I tooke you for Mr. Sconce, but now rejoyce
I was deceived so, I shall study to love you.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Now you name, where is Mr. Sconce?

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Tis my cue now. O father I me here they have given mee a touch, a very scurvy touch, I am a brother of the Twibills, and I am married too, but I need not feare being a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: Mris. you know the Gent.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.l: My servant Lovering married to Mr. Sconce!
You'll get brave boyes I doubt not.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: I and wenches too; come hither, we will be man and wife, that's certaine, nay and lie together, so we will, you shall behave your self well enough like a woman: but that you have a stiff impediment for-bearing Children: but give me thy hand, shal's be drunk together?

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: He is scarce sober yet I thinke.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p:
Ile tell you father, ere I went to the Church I had gotten a touch in the Crowne, the Twibil Knights confusion them on my Jo had made me' drunke, and got my cloathes, and how I came by these
I know not: But ha, let me see, this should be my suite, tis it, by valour it is: doe you heare good man Foxe, how crept you into this Lyons case?

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.p: What meanes this new married man?

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Do you jeare me, with a touch of that? harke you husband, Though I be your wife, you shall not hinder me from claiming my owne Breeches. Mistris a word with you too you put a gentle touch upon me did you not? But I shall know you hereafter, Ile say no more, and touch you boldly for it.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Y'are very merrily dispos'd Sir: had it not beene to have done Sir Martines Nephew, I should not have beene fool'd so. Ile trie his temper though.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.l: No matter Lovring thou art a Gent.
And since I am resolv'd from Master Freewit,
That heele not have me now, (though I were willing)
To toote the least remembrance of him
Out of my breast, by this my happyer choyse,
Ile marry thee.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: But let him marry you though if he dare, ile sue the Statute of Bigamy upon him, he shall be hang'd for being double marryed.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: In this one act
She onely appeares woman, all her Saint,
Speake her a Saint. I did not thinke her heart
Could have resum'd (though than rejected me)
A baser choyse, Sir you've good Fortune: Mris
I will not wish you ill successe in your
So suddaine Love: but it was cruell in you
To give away your soule, (as in despight)
In my loath'd presence: yet to shew how much
I prize your satisfaction, I resigne
My interest in you to him, and thus freely
Bestow him on you: will you have him Lady?

div.stage: Pulls of Loverings Periwigs, he is discovered to be Martha.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Heaven blesse me sister, this is the same maid
Whom Master Freewit is reported to have
Got with Child: this is strange.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Nay, be not amazed Mistris it is she:
You had best call her to a strict account
How long tis since I lay with her.
Know. O Freewit, what meanes this mad delusion?

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: My wife turn'd a woman indeed: this is a touch indeed, I had best bee gone, for feare she challenge me.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: O stay your patience good Mr. Sconce.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Now let heaven, and all that can be titled good beneath
Divinity, conjoyne to frame a piece
Of vertue great as this; yet be deficient
In the atchievement; for some cunning Artist
To draw her in this posture (to be plac'd
(In Alablaster, white as her owne figure)
Or some greene meade or flowry valley, where
Posterity of Virgins yearely might
Offer a teare to the blest memory
Of perfect feminine goodnesse. Let me dye,
Gazing on you and I shall flye to heaven
Through your bright eyes.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Sir, what meanes this extasie?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Ile tell you, and Mrs trust each word,
As the just accent of Oraculous truth:
Knowing your ardent love to me, I feard
It might embrace a change, and therefore shap'd this woman
In the habit of a man got her unknowne to you,
Prefer'd to serve you: (which she could not have bin without
Discovery, in her owne shape) not to o're-looke your life.
Or watch your actions, but to raise report
That I had bin false: so to trye if that
Would stagger your resolve, which I have founde
So noble, that the happinesse of Fates,
Can give no more addition to my blisse.
Madam beg you my pardon.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.l: O sir you have it, and I my best of wishes, but why did you
Employ a woman thus disguis'd suppose
She had beene got with childe you must
Have beene the father of it.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I knew she was too honest, and beside,
I put her to the acting of't because
She being the accuser of me for her selfe
Might without the least scruple of suspect
Free me from her owne calumny, nay here's another,
Can witnesse this for truth.

sp.speaker: Know
sp.p:
How Vrinall Master: Doctor's man turnd to Tristram Mr.
Freewits man, and Marthies brother?

sp.speaker: Vrin
sp.p: So it appeares by the story Mrs. I am glad sir you put my sister in this disguise, she has got a good husband by the shift, take your wife sir, she is no worse a woman then my owne sister.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: But let me see and feele you better, it is no periwigge this but are you my husband, a woman; wife?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: I your wife am sir.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Master Doctor you wish me well I know, I have married here I know not whom, you have excellent salves and unguents sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: They are at your service all.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Thanke you good Mr. Doctor, have you never a one that will eat off the wen of manhood, make all whole before that will eunuchise a man, I would faine be a Hermaphrodite, or a woman to escape this match, I do not like it

sp.speaker: Mris. Mix.
sp.p: Help gentlemen, help Mr. Doctor, yonder is a man would ravish me whether I would or no, nay kild me, I thinke he has puld out the longest naked weapon, O there he is.

sp.speaker: S. Mar.
sp.l: She shall not scape me were she
Fenc'd with fire, strumpet thou diest.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Who's this, Sir Martin, what doe you meane sir?

sp.speaker: Mris.
sp.p: I, this is he Thomas doe you see what a terrible thing hee has got? was that fit to use to a woman? I was but laid in the next roome, to sleepe, and he would have done something to mee so hee would had not I beene the honester woman.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Is't so Sir Martine? I have now just cause
To suspect your loyalty, and that your fond
Jealousie proceeds out of intemperate lust,
Could I not serve, but underneath my nose
You must be rioting upon another?

sp.speaker: Sir Mart.
sp.p: Shame and confusion sease me.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: You may see Sir what comes of your jealousie, but feare not Sir, your wife will pardon it, there's no harme done.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mix.
sp.p: But there might have beene, had not my honesty been the greater.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.l: Well Sir martine, though you have injurd
Me most infinitly, I doe remit all if you will protest
Nere to be jealous more.

sp.speaker: S. Mar.
sp.l: Amasement and my shame hinders my utterance,
Let me breath in sighes my true repentance,
And henceforth
That jealousie in man if't be injust
Is ill, nay worse then in a womans lust.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.l: But pray you brother, who brought you hither?
We shall rejoyce to have you at our wedding,
And see this reconcilement.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: I Madam, I; under pretence to have attempted his wife, but I sent him in to Mrs. Mixum, who I knew would fit his turne.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mix.
sp.p: And so I could have suted him as well as another woman.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Brother Vrinall you are a knave, brother Vrinall, and have showd all a cozening touch.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: No sir I sav'd you from being cozend, my sister shall have some portion, here's a hundred pieces in this purse.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Sinke me my Jo, my owne purse.

sp.speaker: Vrin.
sp.p: It, is indeed Sir, I got it from your Twibill brothers, and this your watch too, and your cloths which Mr. Popingay weares, by locking them into a roome, and threatning punishment, if they denied, the blades shall now resume freedome, this key will let them out, come forth gentlemen, here is your brother Master Sconce.

sp.speaker: Scon.
sp.p: Captaine generall, give thy hand bully, Captaine Pirke, my cosen Pig, and all of you; though you would have cheated me tis no matter, you shall dance at my wedding, and be drunke too, my Joe, you shall.

sp.speaker: Pirk.
sp.p: Confusion rot the bones of Vrinall perdition shall slay him;

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Madam I hope we shall keepe our nuptiall feast with Master Doctor.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.p: As you dispose it sir, I have resign'd my will to yours.

sp.speaker: Pop.
sp.p: Unckle I hope you'l pardon me, that I deceiv'd your expectation in watching my Aunt, she is too vertuous: father your blessing, and then we are happy.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Take it.
Thus all are pleas'd I hope: what this night cannot
(For celebration of these feasts) performe,
To morrow shall, and from this minute I
Renounce all waies sinister to get wealth
Things that ith' period prosperously succeed,
Though cros'd before, are acted well indeed.
